comments.commentBody: Irishgirl, your straightforward, "If one does not like the Catholic rules, do not be a Catholic," is the reason so many of us have left. The secondclass status of women is all the reason I needed (priests unable to marry, the worldwide coverup of the pedophilia, the Vatican banking scandals are some of the reasons others have left.) Neither John Paul II nor Benedict XVI led the Church forward. Looking at the obscene opulence of the Vatican and expecting these old men to be the rolemodels for the impoverished no longer computes.

Not sure why, because I am not a very good Catholic, but I was helped by some very good priests who were very holy men.  Maybe because they were part of an order that looked out for people like me.  I want Mother Church to raise up to the potential of Jesus, but I am also a secular liberal.  Confused, very.  But I found myself saying a prayer for the Pope, for the Church, and that the many wounds caused by evil.  I don't know, I am basically not conservative, but I still have a great love for the Church and want to see our people win.  I want to be proud to be Catholic and to have a Pope I can look to, even when I don't agree.  Maybe nostalgia, but I prayed this morning.  For all of us. I want all of us to heal, to understand that dark as the days, there are holy people, men and women who see beyond the world we live in.

I don't think thoughtful scientists were "dumbfounded" by this.  The paper does not say that mice make poor models of human disease. It says very specific things:  The inflammatory response is different in mice and humans. Therefore finding treatments for inflammatory phenotypes in mice are likely not applicable to humans.  Studies in mice, rats, fish, flies, worms, etc can provide tremendous insights into human biology and disease mechanisms.  But, clearly, identifying drugs that improve inflammatory processes in mice are not applicable to humans,  That is the big lesson here.

I am surprised that so many research scientists were dumbfounded by the result of this study. I am not a scientist, but over the years I have read books and articles attesting to the inadequacy of animal models that mislead more often than not.
And yes, billions of dollars have been wasted. Who knows where we would be now if that money had been spent exploring other alternatives?
It is obvious why the writers found it so difficult to publish these results. It is well documented that the research community is hugely influenced by powerful lobbies that make billions off of animals used in research, and all of the paraphernalia that goes along with it - to say nothing of the pharmaceutical industry.
It is disheartening that some readers have concluded from this article that we should experiment on - aka torture- more chimps. Won't we ever learn?

Monique - The bias against using women in early clinical trials is because healthy young women can become pregnant and in those early studies conclusive teratology is very often not yet available. If something goes wrong in a clinical trial, it is the drug company that will have to pay for the damages no matter who is at fault. Clinical trials are extremely expensive. It is therefore important to determine efficacy as quickly as possible, because if a drug doesn't work, it is important to stop hemorrhaging money. That is why healthy young men are and will continue to be preferred subjects in early clinical trials.

"The paper . . . helps explain why every one of nearly 150 drugs tested at a huge expense in patients with sepsis has failed. The drug tests all were based on studies in mice." I'll be generous here: maybe over the course of testing the first 50 or so drugs, it was just the scientific method in action. After that, the futile pursuit of the same methodology was wasted money. That's how so.

The operative word in your citation is 'correlation'. It's not surprising that someone with highly aggressive tendencies might like violent video games. Of course no one questions this correlation.

What we are really asking is whether or not there is a causal relationship between playing violent video games and acting violently in life.

that is because often the people you shoot in games are, within the story of the game, evil people, criminals who have done bad things. Usually one is assuming the role of a warrior who fights to rid the world of evil - this satisfies instincts that are deeply rooted in many of us. Animals on the other hand, cannot be good or evil, therefore shooting them is very different. Still, if they are threatening in a game (for example, aggressive fighting dogs), then it's a similar situation. You'd never shoot kittens or puppies, just as you would never shoot children in a game - almost none of us gamers would enjoy that in the least, and we don't call that entertainment.

The US Supreme Court has officially ruled that videos of torturing and killing actual living kittens, bunnies, puppies, etc.  for sexual gratification (so-called crush videos) are legally protected by the First Amendment. This same SCOTUS, though, ruled against sexually suggestive drawings of children - which did not involve any actual children - as kiddie porn, a decision which not only comes perilously close to 'thoughtcrime' but puts protecting a non-existent fictional being above the suffering of actual flesh-and-blood creatures. I think that tells you a lot about where our 'values' lie.

I told my kids, it's not good for your heart, to see violent things... Imagine if we made video games that were based on shooting kittens, or puppies. You can see that is morally wrong, to get enjoyment from that. Why is it ok to depict killing people, with lots of gore, and calling that entertainment?

But your Japanese example is highly relevant.

This is a question that can be addressed empirically. There is certainly above all a question ot taste here. My question is not whether these types of first amendment protected entertainments affect us deleteriously but rather how can so many sit enthralled by these tasteless boring predictable displays. The question we should ask of our educational system is not why so many do so poorly on even poorer exams but rather how is it that people nominally "educated" by the system can be habituated to sit fascinated by these horrors. (The same question applys to other art forms such as music, fashion and certain visual arts and all of these are similar to the fast food problem.)

As for the issue of their relation to violent behavior, think about Japan.There the television channels and the cinemas are full of the most violent displays and have been since the time when our own entertainments were far more pacific. Nontheless Japan is not and was not then a particularly violent society. We may quibble over just how violent or nonviolent it is but it is clearly far less violent than our own. If childhood entertainment had anything to do with this that would not be the case.
